This slim novel is as concise as it is cynical. Indeed, you're likely to sigh as you read the goings on of a man who lives his life entirely by instinct, without a trace of introspection or self doubt. I will forgo a synopsis of events, as others have distilled the narrative well enough on this site. I'll just add that I think the author has done a splendid job conveying a type of personality--the beguiling charmer who uses cunning and avarice to get what he wants. But the story isn't just about Georges Duroy's bottomless narcissism. The story is also an expose of the shallowness underscored with dread that was the Parisian Belle Epoque. A truly brilliant novel.

summary: Young, attractive and very ambitious, George Duroy, known to his friends as Bel-Ami, is offered a job as a journalist on La Vie francaise and soon makes a great success of his new career. But he also comes face to face with the realities of the corrupt society in which he lives - the sleazy colleagues, the manipulative mistresses and wily financiers - and swiftly learns to become an arch-seducer, blackmailer and social climber in a world where love is only a means to an end. Written when Maupassant was at the height of his powers, Bel-Ami is a novel of great frankness and cynicism, but it is also infused with the sheer joy of life - depicting the scenes and characters of Paris in the belle epoque with wit, sensitivity and humanity.
